DOC.HEAD: Martinez May Increase Protection; Miami Mayor Under Watch
With AM-Judge-Execution Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez, whose life has been threatened by Colombian drug barons, said Monday he will consider wearing a bulletproof vest following the assassination of an Alabama federal judge. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement has urged the governor to wear a vest during some public appearances, but Martinez said he has never felt comfortable in one. The governor said he would re-evaluate that stance because of the weekend mail bombing that killed Robert Vance, an 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals judge, in his home outside Birmingham, Ala. Brian Ballard, Martinez's director of operations, said the governor probably would wear a bulletproof vest ``as a last resort.'' ``If there was a specific threat, I think maybe he'd put one on,'' Ballard said. ``He doesn't feel comfortable that the governor of the state of Florida should have to wear one of those things.'' Martinez has taken a leading anti-drug role in organizations such as the National Governors Association. Authorities have not linked drug dealers or the Colombian cocaine cartels to Vance's killing Saturday. But Martinez has been threatened previously by drug lords and the bombing drew attention to the governor's security precautions. ``We take into account events like that which just occurred in Birmingham,'' said FDLE spokesman Mike McHargue. ``We're interested in this incident.'' Earlier, authorities disclosed that Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez is under round-the-clock police protection because of threats attributed to factions of the Colombia cartel. ``We're received information indicating there might be a threat to several individuals, including the mayor and governor,'' said Lew Wilson, agent in charge of the Miami FDLE office. Security for the governor has been increased twice in recent months because of the threats and the August arrest of a Miami man suspected of involvement in a plot to assassinate Martinez.
